												I don't think I've ever played a game more irreverent and wacky in its humor and design while also keeping to one of the most accurate and precise physics engines I've seen in a while.Worms Reloaded is actually an updated rerelease of Worms 2: Armageddon (Do not confuse this with Worms: Armageddon. They're actually two totally different games) released in 2009 and while it's one of the older titles in the Worms franchise, it is definintely the one with the most features, gameplay modes, options, and overall fun out of the games I've played.Up to four teams each control a squad of four worms with customizable names, voices, and hats (in fact the Steam version has TF2-themed hats just for this occasion) and an arsenal of weapons ranging from rocket launchers, grenades, flamethrowers, and air strikes to ninja ropes, teleporters, and magnets to a variety of exploding wildlife and grandmas to the mighty meteorific field-wide death of Armageddon.  These worms will use said weapons to blow the living hell out of each other in a manner befitting old-school Looney Toons designed by Michael Bay.  Each worm only has a finite amount of time to make a move, inch across the battlefield, use whatever weapon or item they wish and end their turn.  A surprsing amount of things can get done during this time, but moves must be planned very carefully as just about any situation can be used against you somehow if your opponent is creative enough.The controls on the weapons are all fairly simplistic but at the same time surprisingly complicated.  The physics engine is very in depth taking into account, angle, power put behind the shot or throw, wind power and direction, and the presence of any obstacles.  The precision in which things can be done is fairly impressive and a competent player can do things that might not even seem possible.  It is worthy to note while keyboard controls are present, a controller is generally recommended for this game due to how strange buttons are mapped originally, but this can be changed.  Gravity effects everything BUT the terrain you're standing on.  The randomly generated maps and backgrounds will stay put no matter how many pieces are blown apart until you're either sitting in a crater, traverssing tunnels, or recreating Bastion.  However, even a remaining pixel can be the difference between a hit or a miss in some cases so keeping track of what was destroyed how can sometimes work to your advantage but freak accidents can always happen.One thing that's consistent throughout any worms game, especially in multiplayer, is that no matter how good one side is compared to the other, random chain reactions and other assorted problems can show up as a result of anything happening.  A grenade could be thrown and throw an enemy worm into a mine, which detonates a nearby gas canister that lights an area on fire that eats through the ground and frees up a hole for someone else to fall into- right onto a health crate that fell down previously.  But by no means is this a luck-based game.  Freak happenings aside, the mechanics, complex physics, and sheer creativity allowed in the vast arsenal of weapons and tools requires quick reflexes, careful planning, and a good knowledge of how the game works and mastering these can take quite a bit of practice.While this game is best played with friends, the single-player campaign is long and full of missions ranging from puzzles to challenges, to simply difficult missions and the AI at later levels is surprsingly advanced given how complex the rest of the game is.  Unfortunately, the campaign isn't really worth playing more than once as each mission has a special 'trick' to it that can render it fairly easy in the hands of a skilled player.  The actual multiplayer is where most of the action is.  Randomly generated landscapes of a variety of colors, themes and backgrounds from ancient Egypt to Hell to outer space never makes for the same game twice and customizable maps and game modes allow for more exacting factors to be controlled ahead of time should you wish it.  Due to the antics of how the game works, I recommend you play with actual friends either in person (It's worth noting that local multiplayer only needs a single controller) or online, but online multiplayer is also a perfectly viable option.  Fair warning to those who care, however: There is no word censor in this game and enemy team or word names you come across online can be inappropriate.Overall this is a fantastic multiplayer game that, if plugged into a large monitor, projector, or TV can make a fantastic couch party game that doesn't rely heavily on the RNG, but has just enough chance to allow laughs at a chain of explosions due to a misplaced land mine.  There's enough customization to keep games from getting boring or samey and custom teams are always fun to deal with and it's very easy to personify the little guys and give each of your team a distinct personality or strategy type in your head.  The single-player allows for a lot of time invested and makes for good practice and a rewarding experience by itself.  Still, only get this game if you plan on playing it with friends.

Get ready folks, 2D Worms and back in action!Team 17 presents: The Return of Worms in Worms ReloadedEver since the time the team switched from 2D to 3D, the Worms games had become mediocre. However, the developers have heard the fans voices - reverting back to the old school 2D classic we all know to love! After winning the game in a giveaway, I decided I'd review it right here for you guys!What is Worms ReloadedWorms is a 2D platform game which can be played alone or with friends online.The main attraction to the game is that you can blow your enemies to smithereens, destroying them in any way you want to, whether that be prod of kamikazes!If you wish to know more about the specifics of this game, check them out on steam. As well as this, you can check out the official website here for more information on the entire Worms games series!CampaignIn the campaign mode, you'll compete in up to 35 single player missions, as well as having warzone missions to keep you entertained once those have been completed. As well as this, for those who have never played the game, there is quite an informative tutorial, giving you all the intel required to play and master Worms.As well as this, you also have other game modes to experience. You could try your luck with the bodycount mode, which is basically a survival - beware, only the experienced player will beat this, you'll have to be amazing at the game to survive!As for the campaign, it's not really all too difficult. Planning beforehand and strategizing your movements will allow you to easily defeat the campaign. Along with the side-missions, the single player will probably give you around 10 to 15 hours of solid, fun gameplay.GameplayThe gameplay is the same formula all the other games of the series has used, the movement is done via a simple input with the arrow keys, and jumping with the enter key. Shooting and aiming is done with the space bar and arrow keys (up and down), with different weapons being selected with your mouse.The game is amazingly fun, the unpredictability of the enemy team and the amount of customizability with weapons and other factors make it amazingly fun, giving you the nostalgic feeling of being back in the early 00's playing the old-school Worms game we all know and love.The acrobatic techniques such as backflips and other amazing stunts help you scale platforms otherwise not possible with a normal jump. With many platforms and different maps to consider (though they'll all destructible), the Worms game offers a unique experience like no other!Note; As for the controls, the game can also be played with a gamepad as well. It's absolutely great, works like a charm and is a lot less clumsy than the keyboard and mouse configuration.After playing the game extensively, I'll rate the gameplay 9/10. It's fun, very well polished and comes across as a great aspect of the game.MultiplayerThe multiplayer is really what makes the game what it is. Without it, it'd be a lot less fun and let's be honest, who wants to fire against the AI all day? New features to this great addition to the series include voice chat and the ability to invite steam friends when making a private match.Multiplayer provides two options when hosting matches, private or public games. Once your friend/enemy appears in your lobby, you can start warming up for the battle. There are some options above your name which details the value of worms you have and what color your team will be.Before starting the game, the host is able to choose what level you are going to battle in. As well as the levels included in the game, user-created levels can be used, which is quite challenging and amazingly fun, especially if you have not played the map before.The option for online chat is always there, in every game. Screaming down the microphone is always fun, and with the press of a button you can chat to all your fellow worms within any online game that you play on the servers. It's best to play with friends, but it's also great to take your aggression out on those strangers from around the world!Upon playing this game a lot via online and with a few friends, I'd rate the multiplayer portion of the game around 8/10. There are some flaws and the voice chat definitely needs some work, but other than that it's filled with epic, fun maps that will keep you entertained for many hours.Note: You can play with 2~4 players at once in a multiplayer match, as well as playing LAN if you have some friends over.GraphicsGraphics are amazing to see, there are a lot of new HD effects, all of which enhance the bomb explosions, jetpack animations etc. The developers have also added a nice little feature in the game, the worms scream when in danger.There are also upgrades on the visual and aesthetic measures of the game, including new voices, new gravestones, as well as the addition of odd, funny hats for the worms, which is a welcomed addition to the game too.Because of the vast improvements from the game's predecessors, I'll be rating this game a 9/10 for graphics. It's been vastly improved, giving the Worms games a whole new look and feel to it. Absolutely stunning visuals, especially for a game within this genre!Extra & SpecialsFor everyone who took a pre-order of this, you'll receive exclusive in-game items, as well as the DLC. If you play or have Team Fortess 2, you'll have been rewarded with some special items for that, too.As well as this, Worms Reloaded has a in-game shop, where you can buy hats, landscapes, missions, weapons, gravestones and forts for your Worms.Since the Summer of 2011 there has been alot of DLC releases.ConclusionThis game is worth buying, it brings back the old 2D Worms with a bang and a sense of nostalgia, which is always a good thing. Achievements have made a comeback too, which is always great to see in a game like this.I'd recommend this to all my friends over here! So hurry up and grab this game today! It's time to blast some worms out of the park! NOTE: Old review i wrote for a website.

												If the game is not bad, it is not good either. I could not recommend it because there exists on Steam a better alternative: Worms Armageddon which is the game this one was trying to remake.The term "reloaded" even reflects the dirty hollywoodian habit of rehashing stuff that was already good in the first place (and ultimately failing, remember The Matrix Reloaded?). The problem revolves around Team 17 trying too hard to be worthy of the cult phenomenon that was W.A and satisfying themselves with a paint job and a few additions that are not impressive enough to care about.Graphics sure are improved (although one might object, as I do, that the original sprites were better and that W.A was updated to work with HD resolutions giving a great feel to an "old" game) but maps and weapons are mostly imported straight back from the past (fan service has its limits) even outside of the retro pack DLC and worse: you can only get 4 worms team making rounds shorter and less strategic. Maybe the point was making the game more adapted to casual gamers, but then why make the game less fun in the same place?Then there are the ugly flaws: bad physics as illustrated by the behaviour of the ninja rope or the rebound of grenades (the original had the pride of pixel-perfect precision) and an AI level that can no more be adjusted or even shown on screen making some worms dumb as hell and others able to make humanly impossible shots ("cheating" by using perfect trajectory predictions). Some missions designed to be hard end up just being frustrating.The developers should really move on instead of making the same game over and over and suffer the same fate as Activision. But if you really need a fun game that has great local and online multiplayer as well as a good solo campaign, look no further than Worms Armageddon, all praise the worm!

A right step forward, a good step backwardsBack when I was browsing a certain Scandinavian video game online store I came across a game called Worms Reloaded. At first I couldn't believe my eyes. How could've I missed this game? I decided to take a look what kind of game it was. Seeing only a single screenshot I knew I had to get this game. It reminded me of the simpler times. It reminded me about my old Pentium 2 PC that just barely ran Worms Armageddon.Worms Reloaded is a 2D-strategy game developed by Team 17. The game features a team based action-strategy experience where you have to eliminate the enemy team with wacky and fun wepaons. Those of you who are not familiar what makes Worms game differ from other strategic games is the way weapons, items and environment change the phase of the gameplay. You can use your weapons for dealing damage or blasting your way through dirt. Weapons can be used to modify your surrondings and tools can be used as deadly weapons. The way you use the gadgets you are given is the key to fun and challenging gameplay.The game features different kind of game modes ranging from basic campaing missions to elimination game mode towards more challenging game modes like time trials and puzzles. There's a lot of thing to do and is definetly worth playing even as a single-player experience.Even though Worms Reloaded could be argued to be a modern Worms game it still feels right and controls like a classic 2D-Worms game. It even pays homage to older Worms games by including some older maps in the game. And that makes Worms Reloaded worth buying. It is well made. It is fresh. It is amazing.Lastly, as a bit of a personal suggestion, I would suggest for you to get the DLCs. I usually never get them but seeing how many hours they add to the game (easily 50 hours) it is more than advised for you to get them if you enjoyed the base game.For more recommendations and reviews on our favourite up and coming quality games follow Lot's O Giveaway's group curations here!

TL;DR SUMMARY: This game is not bad at all - in fact, it's very solid and enjoyable, and the graphics are very pretty. But the gameplay is almost the same as Worms Armageddon/World Party, and while new elements are few and mostly cosmetic, a lot of elements (and weapons) from the older games have been removed or have been massively simplified in a bad way. Both older and newer parts of the series have a lot more to offer.FULL REVIEW: So, Worms Reloaded was the series' return to 2D after three 3D games (Worms 3D, Forts, and Mayhem), and as expected, the gameplay didn't change massively from the famed Worms Armageddon and World Party, but the graphics are much prettier, and there are should be some new ideas and innovations... right?Not really. Whether you're interested in playing multiplayer (most people, I guess) or single player (there's probably like 5 of us but we exist), the new elements are mostly details, while some significant classic elements are missing.Let's start with multiplayer. As I said above, the gameplay is more or less unchanged from WA/WWP. Probably the most remarkable innovation is that the maps can now also be vertically, rather than horizontally oriented (i.e. tall and narrow map instead of low and wide), which results in quite different gameplay. There can now also be randomly placed sentry guns (automatically fire at any worms that move) and electromagnets (which seem to only work for the first two turns or so, and therefore don't do much), that also alter the game a bit. There's the good old landscape generator and easy to use manual editor, plus plenty of maps from older Worms that you can use (although they're hidden under "saved levels", which is not very intuitive). No new premade maps with castles, flowers or frogs however, all there is in Reloaded is the generator. Besides regular games, there's also a forts mode and race mode.However, as I said, there's also a lot "less" - especially less customisation when editing game schemes, something like half of the options from the older Worms are gone (e.g. can no longer modify the power of weapons or how often they appear in crates, sudden death is only health drops to 1 and/or water rising, etc.). The "Wormpot" from Worms World Party/Worms 3D (which allowed for such craziness as permanent x2 damage or more slippery terrain) is not here either.But the biggest "less" are weapons - I think something like half of weapons from older Worms are gone, with only a handful of new (and not very spectacular) ones. Most of the crazy superweapons like the Ming Vase or Sheep Strike are gone, but there are also some unique weapons that have been removed with nothing to fill their niche - the most notable being probably the lack of both Minigun and Flamethrower, with no similarly powerful short range weapon to replace them. Another thing that bothers me is the lack of most utilities, like the classic Low Gravity and of course the amazing, wonderful cluster♥♥♥♥ creator: Damage x2 (if you've never used a Banana Bomb with Damage x2, you don't know life, I'm sorry). The only utility left is the Jet Pack (+ Laser Sight has survived using sneaky means, it can be enabled for shotgun as an option), while items such as the Ninja Rope - which is actually a bit harder to use here, a good change, in my opinion, now you actually need to decide between the rope and the jetpack, not "rope gets you anywhere" - or Girder now drop in utility crates instead.As for single player, of course the "less weapons" part also applies, but in this aspect Reloaded fails the most, in my opinion. The campaign here is... bare-bones basically, 3/4 are ordinary deathmatch games which only stop being tutorial-level difficulty about halfway through, and the remaining 1/4 try to be more classic "puzzle" kind of missions, but are also incredibly simplistic - the only genuinely cool and creative mission is the last, 30th one. If you've played the campaigns of older Worms (or especially the masterpiece that was the Worms 3D campaign), and thought a new, more modern engine would mean even cleverer and more intricate missions... nope.avi. A bit better is the Warzone mode, which is basically... also deathmatch, not much different from the campaign, but it does actually get more challenging later on. There's also a Body Count mode which is something actually new - a kind of "survival" mode, but there are no levels to choose from or any options to modify, you only choose the theme and that's it.And while we're at single player, the single biggest proof of laziness in Worms Reloaded - the AI. At first I wanted to say it's "not that great", but after playing for some time, the only way I have to describe it is pathetic. The AI either misses completely (most of the time with lower difficulties) or lands utterly ♥♥♥♥ing RIDICULOUS shots such as "throw a grenade across the entire map which bounces off 4 surfaces into a narrow tunnel and lands under your worm's nose" (this is NOT an exaggeration, I literally mean it). There is hardly ever anything in between, it pretty much doesn't "hit but not direct hit". It seems a tiny bit smarter in making decisions than the old AI, but also that old AI from the 90s did a better job at trying to emulate a human's accuracy and was about 5x more fun to play against, even if it only used like 5 basic weapons or so.On a more positive note, as I said, the graphics are very pretty - the game is very pleasant to look at and feels a bit more spectacular (even though most of the actually spectacular weapons are gone...). Bright and colourful themes are brighter and more colourful (Sports theme! <3 ), while dark and evil ones are darker and more evil. Besides that, there are some new cosmetic elements - when creating your team, you can choose your worms' skin colour and hat (yep, there's hats, and some are actually Team Fortress 2 references). But again, "less"... Only 4 worms per team, end of story.So, that's about it. This is not a bad game at all - if this was the only Worms game ever released, I'd give it praise for being very good and a lot of fun (while also commenting there's a lot of unused potential...). But it's one of a dozen or so at this point, and it just pales in comparison with both the older and newer - whether it's multiplayer destruction and craziness you're looking for, or missions that require strategy and MacGyverish creative thinking, this game has a lot less of both. I just don't see a reason to pick Reloaded over Worms Armageddon/World Party or the newer installments, which seem to have actually contributed some new ideas to the series. (And I now feel sad having to give this game a "not recommended" rating.)

												I love the Worms franchise. They are party games that perfectly mix skill and luck, and do it with such flair that even if you're coming dead last, you never really stop having fun with all the crazy weapons and situations that arise.Worms - Reloaded is I believe the "newest" iteration of this franchise, and I have to say that it isn't really the best... at least in terms of actually being a fun party game to play with friends.Lets go back a decade or so to the playstation one, the good old PSX. Worms World Party had just been released, and it was the most fun I could ask for on a disk-based entertainment system. Sure, the previous iteration "Worms Armageddon" had a fantastic campaign, awesome music, HILARIOUS cutscenes, but as a party game it immediately loses out because A NEW GAME HAS NOTHING UNLOCKED! No weapons, no cool teams, nothing. Just the most basic weapons and voice packs. World Party has everything unlocked from the very beginning, and that made it perfect. He stuck that mother in at a party and went to town on each other's worms.This is not a reason to hate on a game. Some people enjoy there being some challenge and unlockables to collect so you have a reason to play. Smash brothers brawl did this and was a huge hit... would the game have been better if everything was unlocked from the very beginning? Well... I think it would have, but it isn't my place to say.Worms reloaded is the exact same game you played ten years ago. It is exactly the same. Same graphics, same voice packs, same weapons (with a few new ones). We opened this game up to play at a LAN a few days ago, and were immediately disappointed to see that the concrete donkey, the holy hand grenade and the banana bomb were all disabled. Guitar hero learned after it's third iteration that players want everything available at the start, as gamers we no longer valued achievement over fun, we wanted to be able to put in a game and do everything that game allowed us to do. People still say guitar hero 3 was the apex before the series' downfall, thanks to it catering to the 'casuals' of the world. I disagree completely. Like it or not, casual gaming is here, and in many ways, it is better. 												The Worms series has long been held dear by its fans for its endearingly comical, cartoony and unconventionally turn-taken nature of battle, and in my personal regard, offers a gaming experience that I highly value and recommend as an ideal respite from the typically hectic shoot 'em up fare. Whenever I want to relax, have fun and enjoy a good few laughs dispatching foes without the pressure of real time vigilance demanded by first person shooters, Worms is most definitely where it's at.If you're new to Worms, Reloaded is perhaps the best iteration through which to get acquainted with this loveable series. It's visually crisp and vibrant whilst being effortless to run for the majority of systems, with gameplay that is unwaveringly slick and reponsive; a refined culmination of all the earlier iterations that adhere to the classic 2-D visual format.There's one prevalent trait of Worms games that makes them somewhat notorious - it's ever so easy to make a blunder, whether it's by virtue of throwing a grenade only to have it fall in the vicinity of an ally or even bounce right back at you; underestimating the amount of jetpack fuel required to reach your desired destination and then dropping like an ill-fated little stone; fumbling an ambitious attempt to ninja rope across a body of water and plopping straight into it - the list of both witnessed and hypothetical follies goes on, and this is a notable part of what makes Worms so pricelessly tide-turning and amusing although unsuitable for those excessively proud individuals who could never so much as poke fun at themselves!

Posted: June 21, 2014
												If you're looking for a modern Worms game, I'd personally recommend this one over Revolution or Clan Wars.The simplistic cartoon aesthetic, whilst not radically changed in later worms games, is at its finest in this game. It remains truly 2D rather than attempting to add depth with the 2.5D you find in Revolution and Clan Wars. This is just personal preference, but to me it makes the game feel far more... light. Reloaded doesn't try to be more than a lighthearted cartoony atmosphere, whereas Revolution and especially Clan Wars seem to try and add an aura of realistic detail to their themes, one that I personally don't feel matches the series.As far as gameplay goes, this one has the perfect balance between classic and modern play styles. The wide variety of weapons and the various themes leave little to be desired. Also, if you're like me and enjoy customising multiple teams and being able to control all of them on the battlefield, then this is the last game which allows you to do so easily. My main gripe with Revolution and Clan Wars is that the games seem to be tailored for multiplayer, in that you can have one team which has your Steam name as the default team name. You can make more, but the process of being able to play all of the teams yourself is an arduous one. Here in Reloaded, you can simply make as many teams as you wish and line them up to play, be they CPU controlled or player controlled.I'd also like to add that if you ever played the Open Warfare series on PSP or DS, Reloaded is essentially a heavily expanded version of that game. Hell yeah.

Posted: April 7, 2015
												Introduction: Ten years on from Worms Armageddon and the turn-based comic mayhem continues in Worms Reloaded, an all-new edition available for PC through Steam. Worms Reloaded features up to four player online and offline multi-player, voice support, a raft of crazy new weapons and the return of some iconic weapons from the brand’s celebrated past.  We all know and love Worms, Worms Reloaded brings all we love and gives it a new lick of paint. Its all here from holy hand grenades to exploding sheep and even the odd poke for good measure. Story: There is no story per-say to worms, but it does feature a campaign mode that’s pretty comprehensive. Worms is simply about worms at war, there’s no rhyme or reason to it. But you will come to love your own group of worms. Worms has always oozed character and Reloaded is no different.Gameplay: If you have ever played Worms then nothing has changed, but if its not broken why fix it. Worms plays beautifully, even someone who hasn’t played before will soon be comfortable with the controls. In fact I put this to the test when reviewing it, we had a gaming night and after a few minutes my 8 year old had mastered the controls. For me that’s where Worms really shines, Its good to play on your own but even better with friends. There are very few games that span generations, but Worms achieves this as its loved by young and old alike.Presentation: The graphics looked great ten years ago and nothing has really changed, its still those loveable little guys brandishing heavy artillery. It wont push your system even without a discreet graphics card, but its all well drawn and looks great. Worms isn’t about amazing graphics, its about fun. The presentation is great and you really will love these little guys but Crysis its not, nor does it want to be. The animation is smooth and its visually appealing.If you want to read my full review and others visit http://cyberusuk.com

												It's the classic Worms formula, so TL:DR it's a fantastic artillery game and you should definitely buy it.Most of what needs to be said about this game alone has already been said, I'm just going to outline the differences between this and Worms: Armageddon.Pros:Steam integration, easy to set up a multiplayer game and play with friends. Also Steam Cloud saves!Nice graphics that are definitely a step up from Armageddon's ageing '98 256-colour look. Now with cute dancing animations!UI is a bit clunky but much MUCH better than Armageddon's.Enhanced level generator capable of generating more types of levels.Many of the weapons have been streamlined and are easier to use.New customisation options for pimping your teams.New speech banks, while keeping some of the classic Armageddon banks. (it only gets feta!)Integrated speech bank editor.Cons:Only matchmaking, no WormNET/Servers. Online community is dead, go get Armageddon if this is what you want.No LAN support...Generally less weapons/items than Armageddon. (some of them I don't miss)Doesn't seem to be a way to make maps out of images.No cross-platform multiplayer (can't play a game with a copy for a different OS), which doesn't affect me since all my friends use Windows.AI is even worse now. It either does something really stupid or it pulls off a shot with perfect accuracy, even on the lowest difficulty (tends to do more of the latter on higher difficulties).Custom speech banks are not synced by Steam Cloud.Not as much modding support as Armageddon.No Whoopsie speech bank :C (I'll come back y'know!)Some of the content is locked behind DLC, which isn't the case with Armageddon.Overall, I recommend this game to newcomers to the series and people who just want to play with their friends. People who would rather join the Worms community will be better off purchasing Armageddon instead, so long as they can put up with its age.
